{{BMovie}} Cinematic exhibition of the '''[[B movie]]''', defined as a relatively low-cost genre film, has declined substantially from the early 1980s to the present. Spurred by the historic success of several big-budget movies with B-style themes beginning in the [[B movies (The exploitation boom)#New markets for the B|mid-1970s]], the [[major film studio|major Hollywood studios]] moved progressively into the production of A-grade films in genres that had long been low-budget territory. With the majors also adopting [[exploitation film|exploitation]]-derived methods of booking and marketing, B movies began to be squeezed out of the commercial arena. The advent of [[digital video|digital cinema]] in the new millennium appeared to open up new opportunities for the distribution of inexpensive genre movies.
==The B movie loses its place: 1980s== Most of the B-movie production houses founded during the [[B movies (The exploitation boom)|exploitation era]] collapsed or were subsumed by larger companies as the field's financial situation changed in the early 1980s. Even a comparatively cheap, efficiently made genre picture intended for theatrical release began to cost millions of dollars, as the major movie studios steadily moved into the production of expensive genre movies, raising audience expectations for spectacular action sequences and realistic special effects. Intimations of the trend were evident as early as ''[[Airport (1970 film)|Airport]]'' (1969) and especially in the mega-schlock of ''[[The Poseidon Adventure (1972 film)|The Poseidon Adventure]]'' (1972), ''[[Earthquake (1974 film)|Earthquake]]'' (1973), and ''[[The Towering Inferno (film)|The Towering Inferno]]'' (1974). Their disaster plots and dialogue were B-grade at best; from an industry perspective, however, these were pictures firmly rooted in the tradition of star-stuffed extravaganzas like ''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'' (1956) and ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days (1956 film)|Around the World in Eighty Days]]'' (1956). ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'' (1973) and, though not effects-driven, [[George Lucas]]'s ''[[American Graffiti]]'' (1973) were the first serious steps in Hollywood's transformation into an industry built around high-budget B-themed movies. But the tidal shift in the majors' focus owed largely to the enormous success of three films: [[Steven Spielberg]]'s [[monster movie|creature feature]] ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' (1975) and Lucas's [[space opera]] ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' (1977) had each, in turn, become the highest-grossing film in motion picture history. ''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman]]'', released in December 1978, had proved that a studio could spend $55 million on a movie about a children's comic book character and make a very handsome profit. Not an all-time record-breaker like ''Jaws'' and ''Star Wars'', it was merely the biggest box-office hit of 1979.<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=superman.htm ''Superman'' (1978)] part of ''Box Office Mojo'' website. Retrieved 12/29/06.</ref> Blockbuster fantasy spectacles like the original, 1933 ''[[King Kong (1933 film)|King Kong]]'' had once been exceptional; in the new Hollywood, increasingly under the sway of multi-industrial conglomerates, they would rule.<ref>See [[Studio system#The eight majors in the post-system era|The eight majors in the post-system era]] for a record of the sales and mergers involving the eight major studios of the Golden Age.</ref> [[File:BloodSimplePoster.jpg|thumb|left|250px|"Too gory to be an art film, too arty to be an exploitation film, funny but not quite a comedy": 168 private investors kicked in for ''[[Blood Simple]]'''s $1.5 million budget.<ref>David Handelman ("The Brothers from Another Planet," ''Rolling Stone'', May 21, 1987), quoted in Russell (2001), p. 7.</ref> In the tradition of [[Anthony Mann]] and [[John Alton]], brothers [[Joel and Ethan Coen]] brought high style back to the B [[film noir|noir]] in 1984; their intense but ironic take on the genre was [[Joe Dante|Dante-esque]].]] It had taken a decade and half, from 1961 to 1976, for the production cost of the average Hollywood feature to double from $2 million to $4 million—actually a decline if adjusted for inflation. In just four years it more than doubled again, hitting $8.5 million in 1980 (a constant-dollar increase of about 25 percent). Even as the U.S. inflation rate eased, the average expense of moviemaking would continue to soar.<ref>Finler (2003), p. 42. Prince (2002) gives $9 million as the average production cost in 1980, and a total of $13 million after adding on costs for manufacturing exhibition prints and marketing (p. 20). See also p. 21, chart 1.2. The ''Box Office Mojo'' website gives $9.4 million as the 1980 production figure; see [http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/ Movie Box Office Results by Year, 1980–Present]. Retrieved 12/29/06.</ref> With the majors now routinely saturation booking in over a thousand theaters, it was becoming increasingly difficult for smaller outfits to secure the exhibition commitments needed to turn a profit. [[Revival house]]s were now the almost-exclusive preserve of the double feature. One of the first leading casualties of the new economic regime was venerable B studio [[Monogram Pictures|Allied Artists]], which declared bankruptcy in April 1979.<ref>Lubasch (1979).</ref> In the late 1970s, [[American International Pictures]] (AIP) had moved into the production of relatively expensive comedies and genre films like the very successful ''[[The Amityville Horror (1979 film)|Amityville Horror]]'' and the disastrous, $20 million ''[[Meteor (film)|Meteor]]'' in 1979. That same year, the studio was sold off to [[Filmways]], a company with a history in TV production, and was dissolved as a moviemaking concern by the end of 1980.<ref>Cook (2000), pp. 323–24.</ref> Capitalizing on the popularity of ''[[Hercules (1958 film)|Hercules]]'', in 1960 [[Roger Corman]] had made ''Atlas'' for a total of $75,000.<ref>Per Corman in Di Franco (1979), p. 101.</ref> In 1982, [[Universal Studios|Universal]] released a movie in the same tradition: fantasy plus muscles. The lead role was to be played by an Austrian-born actor with a great reputation as a bodybuilder but entirely unproven as a major film star. Adjusting for inflation, the cost of ''Atlas'' was about $400,000 in 1982 dollars. Production cost on ''[[Conan the Barbarian (1982 film)|Conan the Barbarian]]'' was an estimated $20 million.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082198/business Business Data for ''Conan the Barbarian'' (1982)] part of ''IMDb.com.'' Retrieved 1/8/07.</ref> ''Hercules'' had opened in 600 theaters, an astonishing figure at the time.<ref>Cook (2000), p. 324.</ref> ''Conan'' opened in 1,395, making it one of more than twenty movies that year to open at over 900 theaters.<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=releasedate&view=opening&yr=1982&p=.htm 1982 Yearly Box Office Results] part of ''Box Office Mojo'' website. Retrieved 12/29/06.</ref>
Despite the mounting financial pressures, distribution obstacles, and overall risk, a substantial number of genre movies from small studios and independent filmmakers were still reaching theaters. In September 1980, Corman released his most expensive movie to date: ''[[Battle Beyond the Stars]]'', with screenplay by [[John Sayles]] and art direction by [[James Cameron]], cost his [[New World Pictures]] a grand total of $2 million. By comparison, the ''Star Wars'' sequel ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'', which came out three-and-a-half months before the Corman epic, was originally budgeted at $18.5 million and wound up costing $33 million, triple the cost of ''Star Wars'' just three years before.<ref>Mackey-Kallis (2001), pp. 204–5.</ref> Horror was the strongest low-budget genre of the time, particularly in the "[[slasher film|slasher]]" mode as with ''[[The Slumber Party Massacre]]'' (1982), directed by Amy Holden-Jones and written by feminist author [[Rita Mae Brown]]. The film was produced for New World on a budget of $250,000.<ref>Collum (2004), pp. 11–14.</ref> At the beginning of 1983, Corman sold New World; New Horizons, later Concorde–New Horizons, became his primary company. In 1984, New Horizons released a critically applauded movie set amid the [[punk subculture|punk scene]] written and directed by [[Penelope Spheeris]]. Vincent Canby's admiring review ends with a definitive compliment: "''[[Suburbia (film)|Suburbia]]'' is a good genre film."<ref>Canby (1984). Note that [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086589/ IMDb.com's entry on the film] incorrectly states that it was released by New World. Note that in his [http://www.sensesofcinema.com/2006/great-directors/corman/ ''Senses of Cinema'' entry on Corman], Professor Wheeler Winston Dixon makes the following error: "Aimed strictly at the home video and direct-to-cable market, Corman's Concorde films included such titles as Penelope Spheeris' ''Suburbia'' (1984)." Aside from the fact that the Concorde name did not appear on the film, it received a widely reviewed theatrical release.</ref>
Writer-director [[Larry Cohen]] continued to twist genre conventions in pictures such as ''[[Q (film)|Q]]'' (aka ''Q: The Winged Serpent''; 1982): "the kind of movie that used to be indispensable to the market: an imaginative, popular, low-budget picture that makes the most of its limited resources, and in which people get on with the job instead of standing around talking about it."<ref>Petit (1999), p. 1172.</ref> In 1981, [[New Line Cinema]] put out ''[[Polyester (film)|Polyester]]'', a [[John Waters (filmmaker)|John Waters]] movie with an estimated $300,000 budget and an old-school exploitation gimmick: Odorama. In October that year, a gore-filled yet stylish horror movie made for less than $400,000 was premiered at a theater in Detroit.<ref>Cost per Bruce Campbell, cited in Warren (2001), p. 45</ref> The writer, director, and co–executive producer of ''The Book of the Dead'', [[Sam Raimi]], was a week shy of his twenty-second birthday; star and co–executive producer [[Bruce Campbell]] was twenty-three. Retitled ''[[The Evil Dead]]'', it was picked up for distribution by New Line in 1983 and became a critical and commercial hit. Comparing it to ''Night of the Living Dead'', one reviewer said "it achieves a similarly claustrophobic intensity on a microscopic budget. It's a shoestring ''tour de force''."<ref>David Chute (''Los Angeles Herald-Examiner'', May 27, 1983), quoted in Warren (2001), p. 94.</ref>
One of the most successful B-movie companies of the 1980s was a survivor from the heyday of the exploitation era, [[Troma Entertainment|Troma Pictures]], founded in 1974. Troma's most characteristic productions, including ''[[Class of Nuke 'Em High]]'' (1986), ''[[Redneck Zombies]]'' (1986), and ''[[Surf Nazis Must Die]]'' (1987), take exploitation for an absurdist spin. Troma also built on another B-studio tradition: re-releasing the often embarrassing early films of actors turning into major stars. In 1986, the company acquired and distributed two unreleased films, ''Sizzle Beach U.S.A.'' (shot in 1974) and ''Shadows Run Black'' (shot in 1981), capitalizing on performances by [[Kevin Costner]], who had recently appeared in the popular ''[[Silverado (film)|Silverado]]'' (1985) and was set to headline ''[[The Untouchables (1987 film)|The Untouchables]]'' (1987).<ref>Harper (2004), pp. 156–57.</ref> Troma's best-known production is ''[[The Toxic Avenger (film)|The Toxic Avenger]]'' (1985), whose hero, after plunging into a vat of [[toxic waste]] while attempting to escape a loathsome gang of tormentors, mutates into a hideous creature with enhanced physical strength and revenge on what's left of his mind. After the film's successful release, the character, affectionately known as Toxie, became the symbol of Troma and an icon of the 1980s B movie. One of the few successful B-studio startups of the decade was Rome-based [[Empire International Pictures|Empire Pictures]], whose first production, ''[[Ghoulies]]'', reached theaters in 1985. Despite other profitable ventures such as ''[[Re-Animator]]'' (1985), financial difficulties forced the company's American founder to sell it off in 1988.<ref>Morrow (1996), pp. 112–13; [http://www.cinematical.com/2005/10/03/interview-charles-band/ "Interview: Charles Band"] interview by Robert Newton, October 3, 2005; part of ''Cinematical'' website. Retrieved 1/4/07.</ref>
The growth of the [[cable television]] industry in the 1980s helped support the low-budget film market, as many B movies quickly wound up as "filler" material for 24-hour cable channels or were made expressly for that purpose. The broadcast version of the [[midnight movie]] remained popular: the nationally syndicated ''Movie Macabre'' package starring [[Cassandra Peterson]]—aka Elvira, Mistress of the Dark—was essentially a brassier copy of ''[[Maila Nurmi|The Vampira Show]]'', presenting mostly low-budget horror films interspersed with Elvira's satiric commentary and abundant display of cleavage. The video rental market was also becoming central to B-film economics: Empire's financial model, for instance, relied on seeing a profit not from theatrical rentals, but only later, at the video store.<ref>Morrow (1996), p. 112.</ref> A number of Concorde–New Horizon releases appeared only briefly in theaters, or not at all.
==B's in the arthouse: 1990s== By 1990, the cost of the average U.S. film had passed $25 million.<ref name="boxofficemojo.com">[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/ Movie Box Office Results by Year, 1980–Present] part of ''Box Office Mojo'' website. Retrieved 12/29/06.</ref> Of the nine films released that year to gross more than $100 million at the U.S. box office, two would have been strictly B-movie material before the late 1970s: ''[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1990 film)|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles]]'' and ''[[Dick Tracy (1990 film)|Dick Tracy]]''. Three more—the science-fiction thriller ''[[Total Recall (1990 film)|Total Recall]]'', the action-filled detective thriller ''[[Die Hard 2]]'', and the year's biggest hit, the slapstick kiddie comedy ''[[Home Alone]]''—were also far closer to the traditional arena of the B's than to classic A-list subject matter.<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=1990&p=.htm 1990 Yearly Box Office Results] part of ''Box Office Mojo'' website. Retrieved 12/29/06. Dick Tracy literally had been B-movie material—the character was featured in four low-budget RKO films in the mid- to late 1940s. For how espionage and crimebusting thrillers historically were "widely regarded as nothing more than B-movie fodder," see James Chapman, ''Licence to Thrill: A Cultural History of the James Bond Films'' (New York and Chichester, West Sussex: Columbia University Press, 2000), pp. 46–50.</ref> The growing popularity of home video and access to unedited movies on cable and [[satellite television]] along with real estate pressures were making survival more difficult for the sort of small- or non-chain theaters that were the primary home of independently produced genre films. Drive-in screens were rapidly disappearing from the American landscape: between 1987 and 1990, the number in operation fell from 2,507 to 910.<ref>[http://www.drive-ins.com/exbgover.htm A Brief Overview] part of the ''Drive on In'' website. Retrieved 1/2/06.</ref> Surviving B-movie operations adapted in different ways. Releases from Troma now frequently went [[direct-to-video|straight to video]]. As if in farewell, the company brought a title to the big screen in 1991 that summed up much of the preceding three-and-a-half decades of B movies: ''[[Chopper Chicks in Zombietown]]''. Empire's founder, [[Charles Band]], started a new production company, [[Full Moon Features|Full Moon]], specifically to address the direct-to-video market. New Line, in its first decade, had been almost exclusively a distributor of low-budget independent and foreign genre pictures. With the smash success of exploitation veteran [[Wes Craven]]'s original ''[[Nightmare on Elm Street]]'' (1984), whose nearly $2 million cost it had directly backed, the company began moving steadily into higher-budget genre productions. In 1994, New Line was sold to the [[Turner Broadcasting System]]; it was soon being run as a midsized studio with a broad range of product alongside [[Warner Bros.]] within the [[Time Warner]] conglomerate. The following year, [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] launched ''Roger Corman Presents'', a series of thirteen straight-to-cable movies produced by Concorde–New Horizons. A ''New York Times'' reviewer found that the initial installment qualified as "vintage Corman...spiked with everything from bared female breasts to a mind-blowing quote from [[Thomas Mann]]'s ''[[Death in Venice]]''."<ref>O'Connor (1995).</ref>
At the same time as exhibition venues for B films vanished, the independent film movement was burgeoning; among the results were various crossovers between the low-budget genre movie and the "sophisticated" arthouse picture. Director [[Abel Ferrara]], who built a reputation with violent B movies such as ''[[The Driller Killer]]'' (1979) and ''[[Ms. 45]]'' (1981), made two works in the early nineties that marry exploitation-worthy depictions of sex, drugs, and general sleaze to complex examinations of honor and redemption: ''[[King of New York]]'' (1990) was backed by a group of mostly small production companies and the cost of ''[[Bad Lieutenant]]'' (1992), $1.8 million, was financed totally independently.<ref>Johnstone (1999), p. 16; [http://mondofausto.com/interview-abelferrara.htm "Abel Ferrara, Bad Lieutenant"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815203650/http://mondofausto.com/interview-abelferrara.htm |date=2007-08-15 }} part of the Mondo Video website. Retrieved 1/1/07. Online claims that ''King of New York'' was budgeted at $8 million do not appear to be well founded. No reliable figure has been located to date.</ref> Ferrara followed these two movies with ''[[Body Snatchers]]'' (1993), a major-studio remake of the sci-fi classic and an acknowledgment of his debt to the B's of an earlier generation. [[Larry Fessenden]]'s micro-budget monster movies, such as ''No Telling'' (1991) and ''Habit'' (1997), reframe classic genre subjects—[[Frankenstein]] and [[vampire|vampirism]], respectively—to explore issues of contemporary relevance—animal experimentation, ecological destruction, drug addiction, and fin-de-siècle urban romance. Written and directed by Jeremy Horton, ''[[100 Proof (film)|100 Proof]]'' (1997) is based on the true story of a killing spree that occurred in [[Lexington, Kentucky]], a decade earlier. Praising its authentic depiction of the impoverished milieu in which it is set, critics variously described its style as evoking a home movie or a reality-style TV police series.<ref>{{cite web |author=Holden, Stephen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/film/proof-film-review.html|title='100 Proof': Sullen Slice of Sullen Lives|work=The New York Times|date=1997-09-24|accessdate=2010-02-26}} {{cite web |author=Fox, Ken|url=http://movies.tvguide.com/100-proof/review/132519|title=''100 Proof'': Review|publisher=TVGuide.com|date=|accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Joe Leydon of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', capturing the way it crossed the line between genre and art film, called it a "diamond in the rough, or at least a shiny bit of jagged rhinestone."<ref name=Leydon>{{cite web |author=Leydon, Joe|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117432607.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0|title=''100 Proof''|work=Variety|date=1997-03-02|accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
[[David Cronenberg]], one of the leading B-movie [[auteur]]s of the [[B movies (The exploitation boom)#Sleazeballs and slashers: 1970s|1970s]], had stepped up in financial grade with ''[[Scanners]]'' (1980), a $3.5 million production that ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' critic [[Richard Corliss]] associated with his earlier, low-budget films as well as [[George A. Romero]]'s ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'' (1978) and [[John Carpenter]]'s ''[[The Fog]]'' (1980) as "hip parables of contemporary moral malaise."<ref>Corliss (1981).</ref> Cronenberg's crowning achievement in that vein would come a decade and a half later: Like that of ''Scanners'' in 1980, the budget of ''[[Crash (1996 film)|Crash]]'', $10 million, wasn't comfortably A-grade by 1996, but it was hardly B-level either. The film's imagery was another matter: "On its scandalizing surface, David Cronenberg's ''Crash'' suggests exploitation at its most disturbingly sick," is how [[Janet Maslin]]'s ''New York Times'' review begins. The review ends with an explanation of the film's rating: "''Crash'' has the [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#X is replaced by NC-17|NC-17 rating]] (No one under 17 admitted) that it fully deserves. It includes frontal nudity, many sexual encounters and coolly grotesque situations linking sex and violence in graphic, sickening ways."<ref>Maslin (1997).</ref> Financed, like ''King of New York'', by a consortium of production companies, it was ultimately picked up for U.S. distribution by [[Fine Line Features]]. In more ways than one, this result resonated perfectly with the way the film scrambled definitions: Fine Line was a subsidiary of New Line, recently merged into the Time Warner empire—specifically, it was the old exploitation distributor's arthouse division.
==The B movie in the digital age: 2000s== By the turn of the millennium, the average production cost of an American feature had already spent three years above the $50 million mark.<ref name="boxofficemojo.com"/> In 2005, the top ten movies at the U.S. box office included three adaptations of children's fantasy novels (including [[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|one extending]] and [[The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe (film)|another initiating a series]], as well as a [[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory|remake]] of a [[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory|1971 film]]), a [[Madagascar (2005 film)|child-targeted cartoon]], a [[Batman Begins|comic book adaptation]], a [[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith|sci-fi series installment]], a [[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|sci-fi remake]], and a [[King Kong (2005 film)|''King Kong'' remake]].<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=2005&p=.htm 2005 Yearly Box Office Results] part of ''Box Office Mojo'' website. Retrieved 1/2/07.</ref> It was a slow year for Corman: he produced just one movie, which had no American theatrical release, true of most of the pictures he had been involved in recently. ''Bloodfist 2050'', directed by long-time B filmmaker and Corman collaborator [[Cirio H. Santiago]], went straight to DVD in the United States.<ref>See, e.g., [http://www.firecracker-media.com/issue17/interview1701.shtml "Made in the Philippines: Cirio H. Santiago Interviewed"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607010419/http://www.firecracker-media.com/issue17/interview1701.shtml |date=2013-06-07 }} interview by Erika Franklin, ''Firecracker'' webzine, April 2006.</ref> Ultrawide openings at many thousands of theaters were becoming the norm. In May 2007 alone, three fantasy blockbusters—''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End]]'' (third in a series based on an amusement-park ride), ''[[Spider-Man 3]]'' (third in a series based on a superhero comic book), and ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' (third in a series of "family" cartoons)—each opened on over 10,000 screens.<ref>Halbfinger (2007).</ref> As big-budget Hollywood movies further usurped the genre territories that were traditionally the domain of the B's, the ongoing viability of the familiar brand of B movie was in grave doubt. Critic [[A. O. Scott]] of the ''New York Times'' warned of the impending "extinction" of <blockquote> the cheesy, campy, guilty pleasures that used to bubble up with some regularity out of the B-picture ooze of cut-rate genre entertainment. Those cherished bad movies—full of jerry-built effects, abominable acting, ludicrous story lines—once flickered with zesty crudity in drive-ins and grind houses across the land. B-picture genres—science fiction and comic-book fantasy in particular, but also kiddie cartoons and horror pictures—now dominate the A-list, commanding the largest budgets and the most attention from the market-research and quality-control departments of the companies that manufacture them.... [F]or the most part, the schlock of the past has evolved into star-driven, heavily publicized, expensive mediocrities....<ref>Scott (2005).</ref> </blockquote>
On the other hand, recent industry trends suggest the reemergence of something that looks very like the traditional A-B split in major studio production, though with fewer "programmers" bridging the gap. According to a 2006 report by industry analyst Alfonso Marone, "The average budget for a Hollywood movie is currently around $60m, rising to $100m when the cost of marketing for domestic launch (USA only) is factored into the equation. However, we are now witnessing a polarisation of film budgets into two tiers: large productions ($120–150m) and niche features ($5–20m). The rationale is that the likelihood of success is maximised by coupling ultra-large budget and highly marketable features (e.g., ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest]]''), with multiple low-cost bets (e.g., ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]''). Fewer $30–70m releases are expected."<ref name=Marone>{{cite web|author=Marone, Alfonso |url=http://www.spectrumstrategy.com/Pages/GB/perspectives/Spectrum-The-Hollywood-movie-business.pdf |title=One More Ride on the Hollywood Roller-coaster |publisher=Spectrum Strategy Consultants |year=2006 |accessdate=2006-12-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203004153/http://www.spectrumstrategy.com/Pages/GB/perspectives/Spectrum-The-Hollywood-movie-business.pdf |archivedate=3 February 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
''Little Miss Sunshine'' was produced by [[Fox Searchlight]], the major studio's pseudo-[[independent film|indie]] subsidiary, for $8 million. With its quirky, "indie"-style comedy, the film hardly meets any conventional definition of a B movie beyond its relatively small budget, but the sorts of movies embraced by the term have shifted drastically before. Classic [[film noir]]'s combination of visual beauty and verbal wit, for instance, was hardly common coin in exploitation-era B filmmaking. Further expanding the field, [[20th Century-Fox|Fox]] launched a new subsidiary in 2006, [[Fox Atomic]], to concentrate on teen-oriented genre films (horror in particular, at first, then increasingly comedy, as well). The genre focus was similar to that of [[Sony Pictures Entertainment|Sony]]'s [[Screen Gems]] division and the [[The Weinstein Company|Weinsteins]]' [[Dimension Films]], but the economic model was deliberately low-rent, at least by major studio standards. According to a ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' report, "Fox Atomic is staying at or below the $10 million mark for many of its movies. It's also encouraging filmmakers to shoot digitally—a cheaper process that results in a grittier, teen-friendly look. And forget about stars. Of Atomic's nine announced films, not one has a big-name."<ref>Zeitchik and Laporte (2006).</ref> In sum, this was an updated version of a Golden Age big studio B unit targeting a market very similar to the one [[Samuel Z. Arkoff]] and [[James H. Nicholson]]'s AIP helped define in the [[B movies (Transition in the 1950s)#AIP and Corman|1950s]]. Despite its low budgets and consequently low benchmarks for profitability, Fox Atomic's output was seen as unsuccessful by its parent company, which shut it down in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |author=Fleming, Michael|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118002584.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|title=Fox Folding Atomic Label|work=Variety|date=2009-04-19|accessdate=2010-04-27}}</ref>
In a development hinted at by the ''Variety'' quotation above, technological advances are greatly facilitating the production of truly low-budget motion pictures. Although there have always been economical means with which to shoot movies, including [[Super 8 mm film|Super 8]] and [[16 mm film]], as well as [[video]] cameras recording onto [[analog signal|analog]] [[videotape]], these mediums could hardly rival the image quality of [[35 mm film]]. The development and widespread usage of [[digital video|digital cameras]] and [[postproduction]] methods allow even low-budget filmmakers to produce films with excellent (and not necessarily "grittier") image quality and precise editing effects—though technical excellence is no guarantee of aesthetic value or even cinematographic competence. As Marone observes, "the equipment budget (camera, support) required for shooting digital is approximately 1/10 that for film, significantly lowering the production budget for independent features." Comparing circumstances in 2006 to those just a couple of years earlier, he argues that the "quality of digital filmmaking has improved dramatically."<ref name=Marone/>
Independent filmmakers, whether working in a genre or arthouse mode, continue to find it difficult to gain access to distribution channels, though so-called digital end-to-end methods of distribution offer new opportunities. The so-called day-and-date strategy, in a which a film is released simultaneously in theaters as well as DVD and/or cable, may offer a way for the true low-budget B movie to regain some of the audience it has lost.<ref>For a discussion of how day-and-date is being used for independent and foreign arthouse films, see Dargis (2007), p. 19.</ref> In a similar fashion, the popularity of Internet sites such as [[YouTube]] have opened up entirely new avenues for the presentation of motion pictures made on a shoestring. Abel Ferrara, envisioning his first digital film, says, "I want to do it on the Internet...and put it out in 10-minute increments. I know that watching films on computer is the future—it's a direct connection to the audience."<ref>Nelson (2007), p. 66.</ref>
Many of these developments have come together to create a boom in a relatively new form of low-budget genre picture. The fan film, typically an unauthorized production set in the imaginary universe of a popular genre movie or TV series, may be thought of as the most widespread present incarnation of the B movie. "Arguably the first fan film was ''[[Hardware Wars]]'', a short spoof from 1977 depicting toasters and egg-beaters fighting in space," according to journalist Curt Holman. "In the first decade of the new millenni[um], fan films have grown exponentially in quantity and improved significantly in quality and ambition...[t]hanks to digital cameras, affordable editing software and online distribution."<ref name="Holman 2007, p. 12">Holman (2007), p. 12.</ref> In 2002, [[Lucasfilm]] created a yearly award ceremony for noncommercial fan films, arranging to screen them online via [[AtomFilms]] (purchased in 2006 by [[MTV Networks]]). ''Star Wars: Revelations'' (2005), a 40-minute drama directed by Shane Felux for a production cost of $20,000, has apparently been downloaded by millions.<ref name="Holman 2007, p. 12"/> Similar projects are designed as "episodes" set in the TV-based ''[[Star Trek]]'' and ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' universes. A parallel development in fan culture has been inspired in part by the direct-to-video market, whose products garner little notice and less respect in mainstream culture. According to scholar Linda Ruth Williams, the "new B-movie culture runs on the convoluted equation that cheap means bad which means good. Such products garner far more respect from fans because they manage to press the same buttons on one million dollars (or less) rather than one hundred million (or more)."<ref>Williams (2005), p. 288.</ref>
Since 2006, [[The Asylum]]—a production company founded in 1997—has specialized in low-budget pictures also inspired by the big-budget films that have largely usurped the B movie's place in the theatrical market. The company makes what one critic dubbed "[[mockbuster]]s", straight-to-video knockoffs of major studio action pictures: ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'', for instance, is transformed into The Asylum's ''[[Transmorphers]]''.<ref name>{{cite web |author=Potts, Rolf|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/07/magazine/07wwln-essay-t.html?_r=3&ref=magazine&oref=slogin|title=The New B Movie|work=New York Times Magazine|date=2007-10-07|accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> Another commercial relative of the fan film is the overt B-movie homage. [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Robert Rodriguez]]'s ''[[grindhouse (film)|Grindhouse]]'' (2007) nods to a wide variety of exploitation styles popular from the late 1960s through the early 1980s. Criticizing the film, notwithstanding its "posture of cool," as yet another "blockbuster B-movie," Adario Strange places it in historical context: "Despite themselves, Tarantino and Rodriguez have the right idea. As the tools for filmmaking have become cheaper and more malleable, now is the time for rough, ugly, experimental films to shine again as they did in the '70s. The problem for these directors is that they are just too rich, too well-connected and too self-aware to produce films that are truly spit and chewing gum, bleeding-edge like Eric Nicholas' ''[[Alone With Her]]'', [[Vincent Gallo]]'s ''[[The Brown Bunny]]'' or [[Shane Carruth]]'s ''[[Primer (film)|Primer]]''—films most Americans will never see."<ref>Strange (2007), p. 17.</ref>

Published by Mavety Media alongside magazines such as [[Mandate (magazine)|''Mandate'']], it was established in 1993 and folded in 2009.See Kit Christopher & Joe Thompson, "Mavety Media: The Rise and Fall of Socially Redeeming Content," ''Unzipped'' (October, 2009), 10–11. ==Features== The photos appearing in the magazine had various sources; some are obtained from companies that produce gay pornographic films (although most layouts depict individual men, rather than simulated "action" scenes). Photographers whose work appeared in ''Black Inches'' include Anneli Adolfsson, Ken Kavanagh, Brian Lantelme, and Abednego (formerly associated with Mansurf.com). The magazine also carried film reviews, erotic stories, cartoons, and advertisements. ==''Black Inches'' in gay culture== D. J. Murphy's ''Sons Like Me'' starts with a reference to ''Black Inches'' in its first lines:
"What the hell is this, Travis?" My mom yelled as she held the ''Black Inches'' porno magazine in her hand.D. J. Murphy, ''Sons Like Me'' (Lincoln, Nebr.: iUniverse, 2002), p. 1.
Other novels that mention the magazine include John Weir's ''What I Did Wrong''See John Weir, ''What I Did Wrong'' (New York: Viking, 2006), p. 126. and Jim Norton's ''Happy Ending''.See Jim Norton, ''Happy Ending'' (New York: Simon and Schuster, 2007), p. 201. ''Black Inches'' featured every major gay black porn star in photo shoots and interviews, from [[Bobby Blake]] and [[Tyson Cane]] to [[Tiger Tyson]], J. C. Carter, and T-Malone. Bobby Blake writes of his relationship with the magazine, "''Black Inches'' was always very supportive of me. {{Orphan|date=October 2017}}
The '''Brandenburg stone''' is an inscribed stone slab found in [[Brandenburg, Kentucky|Brandenburg]], [[Kentucky]], [[United States]] in 1912, on the farm of Craig Crecelius. The stone contains a strip of linear markings that resemble letters of a script. Crecelius exhibited the stone several times, but was unable to find anyone who could identify the markings.
Jon Whitfield, who acquired the stone in 1965, claims that they are [[Coelbren y Beirdd|Coelbren]], a Welsh-language alphabet. Other writers have elaborated on these claims, arguing that this is evidence of pre-Columbian contact between the legendary Welsh prince [[Madoc]] and Native Americans. The consensus of Welsh scholars is that "Coelbren" is a fake script invented in the late eighteenth century by [[Iolo Morganwg]] in his book ''[[Barddas]]''.
==History== In 1912, farmer Craig Crecelius found the stone artifact in a field near the Ohio River in Brandenburg, Kentucky. The [[oolite]] stone measures {{convert|29|in|cm|}} long by {{convert|15.5|in|cm|}} wide and varies in thickness from {{convert|1|to|3|in|cm}}.<ref name=See /> For more than 50 years, Crecelius displayed the stone at local fairs. At some point, the stone was shattered into three pieces.
In 1965, Crecelius abandoned his pursuit of the artifact's origin and transferred ownership to Jon Whitfield. Eight years later, archaeologists examined the stone and concluded that its markings were actually scratches resulting from a natural process. The stone was stored at the [[Meade County Public Library|Brandenburg library]] until 1995 when it was moved to the Falls of the Ohio Interpretive Center in Clarksville, Indiana.<ref name=CCPL />
In 1999, the artifact was moved to the [[Falls of the Ohio State Park]] Interpretive Center for a year, and then to the [[Charlestown, Indiana]] public library. In January 2012 the artifact was returned to the [[Meade County Public Library|Meade county library]].<ref name=DN-990723 />
==Claims of Welsh origin== [[File:Peithynen - displaying Bardic Alphabet (coelbren y beirdd).jpg|thumb|One of Morganwg's "peithynen" frames containing his "bardic" alphabet]] Whitfield sought evidence that the markings were Welsh in origin. In 1998, the stone was examined by authors Baram Blackett and Alan Wilson, who asserted that the inscription was medieval Welsh. Blackett and Wilson have also claimed to have found the grave of King Arthur and the Ark of the Covenant.<ref>"Historians Battle over Arthurian Intrigue", ''Evening Chronicle'', Newcastle, England, June 12, 2008, p.30.</ref> They translated the inscriptions into English from [[Coelbren (alphabet)|Coelbren]], the script described by Iolo Morganwg, and which modern scholars believe to have been invented by him.<ref name=CCPL /><ref>{{cite web|title=Coelbren y Beirdd - The Bardic Alphabet|url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/888/|publisher=National Museum of Wales|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117215438/http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/888/|archivedate=2010-11-17|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Cathryn|first=A Charnell-White|title=Bardic Circles: National, Regional and Personal Identity in the Bardic Vision of Iolo Morganwg|year=2007|publisher=University of Wales Press|isbn=978-0708320679|page=106}}</ref>
The stone's inscription was translated to read: "Toward strength (to promote unity), divide the land we are spread over, purely (or justly) between offspring in wisdom."<ref name=CCPL /><ref name=DN-990723 /> This was interpreted to mean that it was a boundary marker. [[Jefferson Community and Technical College|Jefferson Community College]] writer Lee Pennington has endorsed claims of the artifact's ancient Welsh origin. The claims have been widely circulated.<ref name=See>{{cite web | url=http://www.meadecountymessenger.com/contentitem/215582/2035/archaeologists-gather-to-hear-story-of-brandenburg-stone | title=Archaeologists gather to hear story of Brandenburg Stone | publisher=Meade County Messenger | date=March 19, 2008 | accessdate=March 24, 2013 | author=See, Larry Jr.}}</ref><ref name=CCPL>{{cite web | url=http://www.clarkco.lib.in.us/history/brandenburgstone.htm | title=Brandenburg Stone | publisher=Clark County (Indiana) Public Library | accessdate=March 24, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430102435/http://www.clarkco.lib.in.us/history/brandenburgstone.htm | archivedate=April 30, 2008 | df= }}</ref><ref name=DN-990723>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gPIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4UcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4713,3166828&dq=brandenburg-stone&hl=en | title=Secretive Stone Gets New Home in Indiana | date=July 23, 1999 | agency=Daily News | accessdate=March 24, 2013 | location=Bowling Green, Kentucky}}</ref><ref name=Holland>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=DoCJUB42lokC&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=Brandenburg+stone#v=onepage&q=Brandenburg%20stone&f=false | title=Weird Kentucky: Your Travel Guide to Kentucky's Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets | publisher=Sterling | author=Holland, Jeffrey Scott | year=2008 | pages=23 | isbn=978-1402754388}}</ref><ref name=Callahan>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=553oiuqBxmkC&pg=PA57&dq=%22Brandenburg+stone%22#v=onepage&q=%22Brandenburg%20stone%22&f=false | title=Lest We Forget: The Melungeon Colony of Newman's Ridge | publisher=Overmountain Press | author=Callahan, Jim | year=2000 | pages=57 | isbn=978-1570721670}}</ref>
==Authenticity== More recently, the artifact has been a subject of several books as well an episode of the [[H2 (TV channel)|H2]] documentary ''[[America Unearthed]]''. Author [[Jason Colavito]] has argued against the stone's authenticity, asserting that it was forged in the 19th or early 20th century when several books promoting "Coelbren" were widely circulated in America.<ref name=Colavito>{{cite web | url=http://www.jasoncolavito.com/1/post/2013/02/following-up-on-the-brandenburg-stone.html | title=Following Up on the Brandenburg Stone | date=February 8, 2013 | accessdate=March 25, 2013 | author=Colavito, Jason}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = town | name = Byron Bay | state = nsw | image = Bryon Bay NSW.jpg | caption = Byron Bay from Cape Byron State Conservation Area | coordinates = {{coord|28|38|35|S|153|36|54|E|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_label_position = left | pop = 9246 | pop_year = [[2016 Australian census|2016 census]] | pop_footnotes={{Census 2016 AUS|id=UCL114003|name=Byron Bay (Urban Centre/Locality)|accessdate=1 October 2018|quick=on}}[[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016050101/https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/# |date=16 October 2017 }}. | postcode = 2481 | elevation= 3 | location1= [[Sydney]] | dist2 = 165 | location2= [[Brisbane]] | lga = Byron Shire | county = [[Rous County|Rous]] | stategov = [[Electoral district of Ballina|Ballina]] | fedgov = [[Division of Richmond|Richmond]] | maxtemp = 23.5 | mintemp = 16.9 | rainfall = 1509.2 }} [[File:Byron lighthouse.jpg|thumb|Byron Bay Lighthouse]] [[File:Byron Lighthouse looking south 2004-28-12.JPG|thumb|Tallow Beach looking south from the lighthouse]] [[File:Wategos.JPG|thumb|Overlooking Wategos with Julian Rocks in the background]] [[File:Byron Bay New South Wales.jpg|thumb|Byron Bay with sugar cane burning in the distance]] '''Byron Bay''' is a beachside town located in the [[Northern Rivers|far-northeastern corner]] of the state of [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]]. It is located {{convert|772|km|mi|0}} north of [[Sydney]] and {{convert|165|km|mi|0}} south of [[Brisbane]]. [[Cape Byron]], a headland adjacent to the town, is the easternmost point of mainland Australia. At the [[2016 Australian census|2016 census]], the town had a permanent population of 9,246. The town is in turn the nucleus of [[Byron Shire]], which had 31,556 residents.{{Census 2016 AUS|id=LGA11350|name=Byron Shire |accessdate=1 October 2018|quick=on}}[[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016050101/https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/# |date=16 October 2017 }}. The local [[Bundjalung people|Arakwal]] Aboriginal people's name for the area is ''Cavvanbah'', meaning "meeting place".{{cite web|url=http://www.theherald.com.au/story/1503982/buck-passing-threatens-aboriginal-lifeline/|title=Aboriginal elders gather at historic meeting place|work=[[The Newcastle Herald]]|accessdate=16 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324075539/http://www.theherald.com.au/story/1503982/buck-passing-threatens-aboriginal-lifeline/#|archive-date=24 March 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Lieutenant [[James Cook]] named Cape Byron after Naval officer [[John Byron]], circumnavigator of the world and grandfather of the poet [[Lord Byron]].{{NSW GNR|id=KWjLjzUlJP|title=Byron Bay|accessdate=28 June 2009}} == History == The history of Europeans in Byron Bay began in 1770, when Lieutenant [[James Cook]] found a safe anchorage and named [[Cape Byron]] after a fellow sailor [[John Byron]].{{cite book |last1=Watson |first1=Penny |editor1-first=Justine |editor1-last=Vaisutis |title=Lonely Planet: Australia |edition= 15|date=November 2009 |publisher=Lonely Planet Publications |isbn= |page= 195 |chapter= New South Wales |quote= The Grandfather of the [...] poet Lord Byron was a renowned navigator in the 1760s, and Captain Cook named this spot after [...] him. (In the 1880s, when Europeans settled more permanently, streets were named for other English writers and philosophers. A star-struck clerk in Sydney thought the grandson was the one being honoured, and named the streets – and the town – after poets: [[John Keats|Keats]], [[Ben Jonson|Jonson]], [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]].)}} The first industry in Byron was cedar logging from the Australian red cedar (''[[Toona ciliata]]''). The timber industry is the origin of the word "shoot" in many local names – Possum Shoot, Coopers Shoot and Skinners Shoot – where the timber-cutters would "shoot" the logs down the hills to be dragged to waiting ships.{{Cite web |url=http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/early-settlement/# |title=Byron Bay Historical Society: Early Settlement |access-date=27 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815012228/http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/early-settlement/# |archive-date=15 August 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Timber getting became insignificant after [[World War I]] and many former timber workers became farmers. Gold mining of the beaches was the next industry to occur. Up to 20 mining leases set up on Tallow Beach to extract gold from the black sands around the 1870s. Byron Bay has a history of primary industrial production ([[dairy]] factory,''Creamery Tramway at Byron Bay'' Longworth, Jim [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]], October 1996, pp. 295–298. [[abattoirs]], fishing, and [[whaling]] until 1963) and was a significant, but hazardous, sea port. The poet Brunton Stephens spoke of cattle grazing on the "mossy plains" of Cape Byron in a poem he penned in 1876. The first [[jetty]] was built in 1886, and the railway was connected in 1894, and Cavvanbah became Byron Bay in 1894. Dairy farmers cleared more land and settled the area. In 1895, the [[Norco Co-operative]] was formed to provide cold storage and manage the dairy industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.norco.com.au/publish/history/index.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=7 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012104655/http://www.norco.com.au/publish/history/index.php |archivedate=12 October 2008 }} The introduction of [[paspalum]] improved production, and Byron Bay exported butter to the world. The Norco factory was the biggest in the southern hemisphere,{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} expanding from dairy to [[bacon]] and other processed meat. The [[lighthouse]] was built in 1901 at the most easterly point on the Australian mainland. In 1930, the first meatworks opened.{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Beauty-and-the-beast/2005/03/20/1111253864398.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Beauty and the beast | date=20 March 2005 | access-date=7 October 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410102812/http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Beauty-and-the-beast/2005/03/20/1111253864398.html# | archive-date=10 April 2008 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} The smell from the meat and dairy works was, by all accounts, appalling,{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} and the annual slaughter of migrating whales in the 1950s and 1960s made matters worse. [[Sand mining]] for [[monazite]] ([[zircon]], [[uranium]] and [[thorium]]) between the World Wars damaged the environment further,[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/planmanagement/final/20120399CumbebinSwampNRFinal.pdf Cumbebin swamp nature reserve] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625123057/http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/planmanagement/final/20120399CumbebinSwampNRFinal.pdf# |date=25 June 2014 }} ''[[National Parks and Wildlife Service (New South Wales)]]'' page 20{{cite web|url= http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/population/ |title=Industry|date=19 June 2014|publisher= |accessdate=28 September 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170310191149/http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/population/ |archive-date=2017-03-10 |dead-url= no }}{{cite web|url=https://mrdata.usgs.gov/ree/show-ree.php?rec_id=514|title=Newrybar (Record #514 rare-earth element deposit in New South Wales, Australia|work=mrdata.usgs.gov|accessdate=28 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929000925/https://mrdata.usgs.gov/ree/show-ree.php?rec_id=514#|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and one by one, all these industries declined.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} [[Longboard (surfing)|Longboard]] [[Surfing|surfers]] arrived in the 1960s and used natural breaks at The Pass, Watego's, and Cosy Corner. This was the beginning of Byron Bay as a travellers' destination, and by 1973, when the [[Aquarius Festival]] was held in nearby [[Nimbin, New South Wales|Nimbin]], its reputation as a [[hippie|hippy]], happy, [[alternative lifestyle|alternative]] town was established, although tourism facilities remained minimal.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=YwkuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA55|pp=55-63|title=New Voices, New Visions: Challenging Australian Identities and Legacies|editor1=Catriona Elder|editor2=Keith Moore|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|year=2012|ISBN=1-4438-3756-3|access-date=28 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929001056/https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=YwkuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA55#|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} From the 1980s, tourism began to develop in earnest, with the cash-poor surfers and hippies supplemented, and to a degree supplanted, by cashed-up conspicuous consumers who in turn stimulated the development of retail precincts and accommodation more tuned to their needs. Today, Byron Bay is one of the most up-market residential areas on the Australian east coast with the growth in multi-million dollar mansions now pushing the median value of house sales up beyond AU$1.5 million in 2017, over a 100% increase since 2013, based on 2018 data from realestate.com.au.[https://www.realestate.com.au/invest/house-in-byron+bay,+nsw+2481 realestate.com.au data for Byron Bay, NSW] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180827142504/https://www.realestate.com.au/invest/house-in-byron+bay,+nsw+2481# |date=27 August 2018 }} (retrieved 27 August 2018) At the same time, the town has not lost its attraction to a diverse range of visitors including surfers, backpackers and general tourists interested in the natural attractions of the area, and also supports a healthy cross section of creative persons including artists, craftspersons and musicians, while its more recent hippy/new age past is reflected to a degree in a prevalence of alternative "new-age" shops, "spiritual" services such as meditation and yoga classes, and holistic healing/"wellness" retreats.Wray, Meredith, Laing, Jennifer and Voigt, Cornelia. 2010. "Byron Bay: an alternate health and wellness destination." ''Journal of Hospitality and Tourism Management'' Volume 17, Issue 1, Pages 158-166. DOI:10.1375/jhtm.17.1.158 As at 2018, the town is cited as having around 5,000 permanent residents, while being visited by over 1.5 million tourists each year.[http://www.destinationbyron.com.au/our-shire/ Destination Byron: Our Shire] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828072605/http://www.destinationbyron.com.au/our-shire/# |date=28 August 2018 }} (entry for Byron Bay) A number of shipwrecks litter the bay and surrounding areas.NSW Heritage office: "Shipwrecks - Byron Bay." Available online at https://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/heritagebranch/maritime/shipwrecksbyron.pdf == Population == According to the [[Census in Australia#2016|2016 census]] of Population, there were 9,246 people in Byron Bay. * Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 1.6% of the population. * 64.0% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 4.9% and New Zealand 2.5%. * 76.3% of people spoke only English at home. * The most common response for religion was No Religion at 44.6%. == Geography == Byron Bay is part of the erosion [[caldera]] of an ancient [[shield volcano]], the [[Tweed Volcano]], which had erupted 23 million years ago. The volcano formed as a result of the [[Indo-Australian Plate]] moving over the [[East Australia hotspot]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bigvolcano.com.au/natural/lostwrld.htm|title=The Lost World|publisher=Big Volcano Visitor Guide|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130314025525/http://www.bigvolcano.com.au/natural/lostwrld.htm#|archive-date=14 March 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} == Climate == Byron Bay has a [[humid subtropical climate]] (''Cfa'' in the [[Köppen climate classification]]) with warm summers and mild winters. Winters have daily maximums usually reaching 19.4 °C and a minimum of 12 °C. Summer can be hot, with a daily average of 27 °C. Summer evenings can be wet, cooling the day down.

== Tourism == [[File:Byron Bay (Australia) main Beach from town.JPG|thumb|The main beach in 2006]] [[File:Byron Bay Lighthouse.JPG|thumb|[[Cape Byron Light|Byron Bay Lighthouse]]]] The town has several beaches which are popular for [[surfing]]. It is a resort popular with both domestic and international tourists, including [[backpacking (urban)|backpackers]], who travel along the Australian coast; the scenery also attracts skydivers. The area is also noted for its wildlife, with the [[whale watching]] industry a significant contributor to the local economy.{{cite web|url=http://www.visitnsw.com/destinations/north-coast/byron-bay-area/byron-bay|title=Byron Bay|publisher=Visit NSW|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121208035053/http://www.visitnsw.com/destinations/north-coast/byron-bay-area/byron-bay#|archive-date=8 December 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} An [[oceanway]] runs from the centre of town to the Cape Byron lighthouse. This allows visitors to walk and cycle to the lighthouse. Temperate and tropical waters merge at Byron Bay, making it a popular area for [[scuba diving]] and [[snorkelling]]. Most diving is done at [[Julian Rocks]] which is part of the recently established [[Cape Byron Marine Park]] and only a few minutes boat ride from Main Beach.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} Byron Bay also lies close to subtropical rainforests, and areas such as the [[Nightcap National Park]] with the [[Minyon Falls]] are all within easy reach of the town. Byron Bay is now also a popular destination for [[Schoolies week]] during late November and early December.{{cite news|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/byron-bay-schoolies-put-gold-coast-to-shame-20091130-jzb8.html|title=Byron Bay Schoolies 'put Gold Coast to shame'|date=30 November [[Triathlon]] is held on the second Saturday in May every year. 1,300 competitors from many different countries enter this Olympic Distance event. The vibrant musical community has produced internationally renowned bands such as [[Blue King Brown]], [[Parkway Drive (band)|Parkway Drive]] and [[50 Lions]]. ==Markets== Byron Bay has a number of regular markets including a weekly [[farmers' market]]{{cite web|url=http://byronfarmersmarket.com.au/|title=Byron Farmers' Market|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813000706/http://byronfarmersmarket.com.au/#|archive-date=13 August 2011|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} at the Butler Street Reserve every Thursday with over 70 local farmers selling fresh produce. There is also a Byron Community Market held on the same site on the first Sunday of each month and the Artisan Market held on Saturday evenings at Railway Park from October to Easter. There are three annual specialist Beachside Markets held in January, Easter and September.{{cite web|url=http://www.byroncentre.com.au/|title=Byron Markets|publisher=Byron Community Centre|accessdate=15 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141215054341/http://www.byroncentre.com.au/#|archive-date=15 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Transport== A bus station in Jonson Street is serviced by [[Greyhound Australia]], [[NSW TrainLink]] and [[Premier Transport Group|Premier Motor Services]] coach services from [[Sydney]] and [[Brisbane]]. The [[Byron Bay Railroad Company|Byron Bay Train]] service will operate as a shuttle between Byron Bay station in the Byron township and North Beach station. The privately run service operates on a 3 km section of the disused [[Murwillumbah railway line|Murwillimbah line]]. It is expected to open by Christmas 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadsheet.com.au/national/city-file/article/worlds-first-solar-powered-train-heads-byron-bay|title=The World’s First Solar-Powered Train Heads to Byron Bay|work=Broadsheet|access-date=2017-10-29|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029121255/https://www.broadsheet.com.au/national/city-file/article/worlds-first-solar-powered-train-heads-byron-bay#|archive-date=29 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} [[Byron Bay railway station]] was a stop on the [[Murwillumbah railway line|Casino to Murwillumbah railway line]] until 2004. It was served by trains from Sydney and for various periods also by services originating at Casino that connected with expresses running between Sydney and South Brisbane. A 3.4 km section of the Murwillumbah railway line is to be rehabilitated in 2016 for a two car self-propelled diesel train planned to run from the town centre to the Elements of Byron resort and nearby attractions. An earlier local train service, known as the Byron Bay Tram conveyed passengers from about 1928 until about 1954 between the railway station and the "new jetty" where connections were made with passenger carrying ships of the North Coast Steam Navigation Company. Motive power was a Simplex petrol locomotive, locally known as the "Green Frog", and the passenger vehicles comprised former Newcastle B2 class steam tram trailer 74B and former Sydney C class electric tram C37. After the trams stopped running both the cars went to a heritage tramway in Parramatta Park where 74B was destroyed by fire. The Simplex was built in Bedford England and went into service in 1923 shunting freight to and from the "old" jetty adjacent to the township and then to "new" jetty to the north when it was completed in 1928. Later it hauled whales from the jetty to the rendering down works, livestock to the meat works, mineral sands and meat wagons to the station for onward movement and regularly shunted Norco and other railway sidings and between these duties ran the passenger tramway until the coastal passenger shipping service stopped. The Simplex locomotive was retired in 1984 when the meat works closed and is now stored in a shed near the Kendall Street level crossing under the care of volunteers and the Byron Bay Council. == Education == Byron Bay schools include Byron Bay Public School, [[Byron Bay High School]], St Finbarr's Primary School, Byron Bay Community School, and [[Cape Byron Rudolf Steiner School]]. Among these are a number of early childhood facilities including Byron Bay Preschool and Periwinkle Preschool. In the fields of adult education there are Lexis English Centres (previously Global Village English Centres) and Byron Bay English Language School (BBELS) (both organisations providing English language tuition to international students), the Byron Region Community College, which is a registered training organisation and the SAE Institute Byron Bay which is a government-accredited, degree granting institution in the fields of audio engineering, digital film making, multimedia and animation. == Sport and recreation == The Byron Bay Surf Club is the longest-standing current sports club; it has been one of Australia's leading surf clubs and has been in continuous operation for more than 105 years. The [[rugby league]] club the [[Byron Bay Red Devils]] and the [[Australian rules football]] team [[Byron Football Club|Byron Magpies]] are well known. Byron Bay FC has won the Football Far North Coast Premier league three times, most recently in 2013. Other clubs include Byron Bay Golf Club, Byron Bay Cricket Club, Byron Bay Rugby Union Club, Byron Bay Gliding Club, Byron Bay Hang Gliding / Paragliding Club and the Byron Bay Bowling Club. The Byron Bay Ocean Swim Classic is held every year. == Media == The Byron Bay area has a number of newspapers: * ''The [[Byron Shire Echo]]'' (Independent weekly A3) * ''The Byron Shire News'' (APN weekly A3) * ''The Saturday Star'' (Independent A5 monthly) * ''The Bagg'' (Independent weekly A3 gig guide) * ''[[The Northern Star]]'' (APN daily, produced in nearby [[Lismore, New South Wales|Lismore]]) The community radio station [[Bay FM (Byron Bay)|Bay FM]] broadcasts on 99.9 FM from within Byron Bay itself. [[File:CharroOutfitsNoreste09.JPG|thumb|Charro suit from early 20th century.]] A '''charro''' or '''charra outfit''' or '''suit''' (''traje de charro'', in [[Spanish language|Spanish]])<ref name="Britannica">{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/art/mariachi#ref878892|title=Mariachi|last=|first=|date=|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en}}</ref> is a style of dress originating in [[Mexico]] and based on the clothing of a type of horseman, the [[charro]]. The style of clothing is often associated with [[mariachi]] and [[ranchera music]] performers, [[History of Mexico|Mexican history]], and celebration in festivals. The charro outfit is one that is associated with Mexico around the world. It is seen as a national emblem and a way to express personal pride in Mexican heritage. Charro outfits can be worn by men or women and have various levels of formality from work-wear to very expensive formal attire. The outfits consist of tight, decorated pants or a long skirt, short jackets, silk ties and are often worn with a wide-brimmed [[sombrero]] and other accessories as appropriate.
== About == [[File:Charra_outfit.jpg|thumb|Charra outfit designed by [[Malena Cano]].]] A basic charro outfit worn by men consists of long, tight pants covered with decoration on the sides.<ref name="Survives">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22981801/|title=The Charro Spirit Survives and Suits Us Well|last=Gurza|first=Agustin|date=14 September 1999|work=The Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The coat worn by both men and women is short and [[Embroidery|embroidered]].<ref name="Survives" /> These coats are also known as bolero jackets or ''chaquetillas''.<ref name="GERay">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22983175/|title=Rodeo: It's a Violent Sport South of the Border|last=Ray|first=Grace Ernestine|date=10 May 1942|work=Arizona Republic|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="HCFashion">{{Cite news|url=https://hauteculturefashion.com/charro-mexican-cowboy-costume/|title=Charro: A Brief History Of How The Mexican Cowboy Became a National Fashion Symbol – Haute Culture Textile Tours|last=|first=|date=2018-05-08|work=Haute Culture Textile Tours|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en-US}}</ref> Embroidery often depicts plant life, [[Aztecs|Aztec]] motifs or other themes.<ref name="HCFashion" /> Traditionally, the embroidery was made of [[Metallic fiber|metallic thread]] or of pitea fiber.<ref name="HCFashion" /> Charro outfits also consist of a wide-brimmed hat ([[sombrero]]) and silk tie.<ref name="Britannica" /><ref name="Survives" /> The charra outfit for women is similar, with women wearing a long, embroidered skirt, reaching the ankles, instead of the pants.<ref name="Survives" /> The skirt is typically full enough to allow the woman to ride [[sidesaddle]].<ref>{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Hernández-Ehrisman |first=Laura |title=Inventing the Fiesta City: Heritage and Carnival in San Antonio |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-l4-58Wvxu0C&pg=PA143 |year=2008 |publisher=University of New Mexico Press |location=Albuquerque, New Mexico |isbn=978-0-8263-4310-9 | page=143}}</ref> Other aspects of the outfit may include a dress shirt, [[chaps]], [[serape]] and pitea belt.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22982958/|title=Devotion to the Charreada Must Come From the Heart|last=England|first=Nelson|date=16 September 1986|work=Austin American-Statesman|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martinón-Torres|first=Lucas|date=2010|title=The Mexican Charro Suit, A Uniform of Tradition|url=http://www.revistasexcelencias.com/en/caribbean/again/reportaje/mexican-charro-suit-uniform-tradition|journal=Caribbean|volume=|issue=37|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name="HCFashion" /> The outfits are often colorful.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22983109/|title='Charro Days Will Give|last=|first=|date=7 March 1938|work=The Brownsville Herald|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The footwear is either a high-heeled boot, or a leather shoe.<ref name="Taboo" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22985912/|title=Cowboy Boots Taboo With Charro Outfit|last=|first=|date=9 February 1947|work=The Brownsville Herald|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
Different versions of the charro outfit are ranked based on a 1960 decision of the [[National Charro Federation]].<ref name="Mexico.mx">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mexico.mx/en/articles/the-charro-suit-mexican-tradition|title=The charro suit: Mexican tradition|last=|first=|date=7 December 2017|website=Mexico|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> The least formal is known as the ''faena'' or work outfit.<ref name="Mexico.mx" /> The next levels are ''media gala'', ''gala'', ''gran gala'' and ''etiqueta'' or formal.<ref name="Mexico.mx" /> [[Mariachi]] performers wear a version of a charro outfit called the "gala version" and is most often black with silver, though modern mariachis wear more colorful outfits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mariachimusic.com/about/history/mariachi-attire/|title=Mariachi Attire|last=|first=|date=|website=Mariachi Music|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> The ''faena'' outfit is unadorned and typical of working charros.<ref name="Mexico.mx" />
An expensive charro outfit was reported in a 1942 edition of the ''[[The Arizona Republic|Arizona Republic]]'' that was decorated in silver and "evaluated at 10,000 [[Peso|pesos]]."<ref name="GERay" />In 1985, Victor Almaraz of California made a charro outfit consisting mainly of around 2,500 interlocking [[aluminum can]] [[Drink can#Pop-tab|pull tabs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22982815/|title=El Charro|last=Hendricks|first=Dan|date=6 September 1985|work=The San Bernardino County Sun|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
The charro outfit is seen as a representative [[symbol]] of Mexican culture.<ref name="Inaugurates">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22986121/|title=Mexico City Inaugurates 'Charro' Cops|last=|first=|date=10 December 2002|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22995034/|title=Something Different|last=Chang|first=Daniel|date=9 December 2000|work=El Paso Times|access-date=2018-08-21|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The outfit and other charro imagery is often incorporated in [[Tourism|tourist]] advertisements and has become one of the "most universally recognized emblem of Mexican identity around the world."{{Sfn|Conway|2017|p=68}} The charro suit can be worn to express pride for Mexican heritage.<ref name="Survives" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-162698789.html|title=Many in Latino Community Shocked|last=Salinas|first=Claudia Melendez|date=26 April 2007|work=The Monterey County Herald|access-date=20 August 2018|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref>
== History == The origins of the charro outfit may be traced back to [[Salamanca]] of the [[16th century]].<ref name="Survives" /> Spanish [[Conquistador|conquistadors]] brought this type of clothing with them to Mexico.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22994922/|title=Just What Is a Charro? Charlie Explains It All|last=|first=|date=16 February 1944|work=The Brownsville Herald|access-date=2018-08-21|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> When [[Spain]] colonized Mexico, the government initially made it illegal for indigenous Mexicans to ride horses without Spanish landowner permission.<ref name="HCFashion" /> This was part of a system that created the ''casta'' or [[Caste|caste system]] in Mexico.{{Sfn|Márquez|2018|p=35}} When the Spanish allowed lower classes to ride, they were required to wear clothing that differentiated themselves from the Spanish, which led to a new fashion.<ref name="HCFashion" /> The wide brim of the [[sombrero]] worn by [[Charro|charros]] protected them both from the sun and, due to the hard crown, from head injuries.<ref name="Taboo">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22985754/|title=Do You Know That... A Tour of Mexico in Los Angeles|last=Rodriguez|first=Raul|date=17 May 1931|work=The Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-08-20|page=7|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}} and {{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22985651/|title=Did You Know That|last=|first=|date=17 May 1931|work=The Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-08-20|page=18|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The pants were worn tight to prevent snagging on brush, or [[chaparral]] and the coat worn short to provide better access to weaponry.<ref name="Taboo" /> Charros were considered part of the lower class in [[17th century]] Mexico. The word ''charro'' was a derogatory term, originally meant to indicate their class status.{{Sfn|Márquez|2018|p=35-36}}
After the [[Mexican Revolution]], the imagery of the charro became important to Mexican culture.{{Sfn|Conway|2017|p=69}} Mexican president, [[Porfirio Díaz]], influenced [[mariachi]] performers to adopt the charro costume in the early 1900s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Betz|first=Virginia Marie|date=1995|editor-last=Sands|editor-first=Kathleen Mullen|title=On the History of the Mexican Charro: A Review Essay|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/40169936|journal=Journal of the Southwest|volume=37|issue=3|pages=512|registration=yes|via=JSTOR}}</ref><ref name="Magic">{{Cite news|url=http://magazine.ucla.edu/features/the-magic-of-mariachi/|title=The Magic of Mariachi|last=Marquez|first=Letisia|date=1 October 2013|work=UCLA Magazine|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> Mariachi musicians would accompany [[ranchera]] singers starting in the 1930s and in the 1940s ranchera musicians adopted the charro suit.<ref name="Magic" />{{Sfn|Conway|2017|p=71}}
Since 1934, September 14th is the national holiday known as the ''Día Nacional del Charro'' (National Day of the Charro) and is celebrated throughout Mexico to recognize the importance of horsemen and women to the culture of the country.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mexico celebrates Día del Charro |url=https://www.vallartadaily.com/mexico-celebrates-charro-tradition/ |accessdate=23 August 2018 |publisher=''Vallarta Daily News'' |date=September 14, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180823145924/https://www.vallartadaily.com/mexico-celebrates-charro-tradition/ |archivedate=23 August 2018 |location=Puerto Vallarta, Mexico}}</ref> Festivities include parades and shows of horsemanship, with riders in the iconic traditional costume.<ref>{{cite web |title=Celebran Día del Charro en Monumento a la Patria |url=http://www.yucatan.gob.mx/saladeprensa/ver_nota.php?id=200932 |accessdate=23 August 2018 |publisher=Government of the State of Yucatan |date=September 14, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180823150321/http://www.yucatan.gob.mx/saladeprensa/ver_nota.php?id=200932 |archivedate=23 August 2018 |location=Mérida, Yucatán, Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=Celebrate the Day of the Charro at the Monument of Patrimony}}</ref> Spanish poet Manuel Benítez Carrasco, in describing the importance of the outfit stated, "Vestirse de charro es como vestirse de México" (Dressing as a charro is like dressing up as Mexico).<ref>{{cite news |title=Así celebra México el Día Nacional del Charro |url=https://www.telesurtv.net/multimedia/Asi-celebra-Mexico-el-Dia-Nacional-del-Charro-20170914-0071.html |accessdate=23 August 2018 |agency=[[EFE]] |publisher=''[[El Siglo de Torreón]]'' |date=14 September 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003150909/https://www.telesurtv.net/multimedia/Asi-celebra-Mexico-el-Dia-Nacional-del-Charro-20170914-0071.html |archivedate=23 August 2018 |location=Torreón, Coahuila, Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=This is how Mexico celebrates National Charro Day}}</ref> The outfit was further popularized by actors who wore the charro suit in movies made during the [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema|Golden Age of Mexican Cinema]].<ref name="Mexico.mx" />
In 2002, police officers in [[Mexico City]] began to wear charro outfits on patrol in the city's historic districts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22981507|title=Police Donning 'Charro' Outfits|last=|first=|date=14 September 2002|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The officers were meant to both "entertain and protect the tourists that flood the Central Alameda area."<ref name="Inaugurates" />
== In popular culture == Charro outfits were worn in the [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema|Golden Age of Mexican Cinema]] by actors such as [[Jorge Negrete]], [[Pedro Infante]], [[Emilio Fernández]], [[Pedro Armendáriz]] and [[Luis Aguilar (actor)|Luis Aguilar]].<ref name="Mexico.mx" /> The character, [[Gordo (comic strip)|Gordo]], in the eponymous comic strip by [[Gus Arriola|Gustavo Arriola]], was portrayed dressed in charro outfits.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-174315538.html|title=Cartoonist Drew 'Gordo,' Celebrating Hispanics|last=Rourke|first=Mary|date=6 February 2008|work=The Virginian-Pilot|access-date=20 August 2018|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref> The children's story, ''La Fiesta y el Mariachi'' by Marta Arroyo, describes traditional Mexican clothing, including the charro outfit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1324695641.html|title=A Mariachi Crash-Course for Children and Grown Ups, Too!|last=Sáinz|first=Pablo Jaime|date=13 July 2007|work=La Prensa San Diego|access-date=20 August 2018|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref> An annual celebration known as [[Charro Days]] in [[Brownsville, Texas]] incorporates the charro outfit among many participants and attendees.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22960706/|title=Charro Costumes Are Cheap and Easy to Make|last=|first=|date=10 February 1942|work=The Brownsville Herald|access-date=2018-08-21|language=en|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>

revision.comment: Expand the definition, based on decades of personal experience
revision.text:
A '''clock chime''' is a melody or a set of melodies played at intervals upon a set of bells to mark the passage of time. It is also the name of such a set of bells when they are not part of a larger bell instrument such as a [[carillon|carillon]]. It is distinct from the striking of the hour by a single bell, although a clock that plays a clock chime normally plays the associated hour strike as well, while the hour bell may or may not have a part in the melodies. The bells used to play clock chimes are most commonly located in [[bell tower|bell towers]] or [[grandfather clock|grandfather clocks]], but may be found in other places as well. A variety of melodies exist, many associated with a particular location or bell tower that originated them.<ref>{{cite web |title=A Compilation of Clock Chimes & Sequences|url=http://www.nawcc.org/images/stories/2010/articles/2015/415/415_267_277.pdf |date=May 2015 |publisher=NAWCC Watch & Clock Bulletin |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Mallory, Steven R.}}</ref>
== History ==
The practice of using bells to mark time dates at least to the time of the early [[Christian church]], which used bells to mark the "canonical hours".<ref>{{cite web |title=Bells: their history, legends, making, and uses |url=https://archive.org/stream/bellstheirhistor00cole/bellstheirhistor00cole_djvu.txt |date=1928 |publisher=Rand, McNally & Company |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Coleman, Satis Narrona}}</ref> An 8th-century Archbishop of York gave his priests instructions to sound church bells at certain times, and by the 10th century [[Saint Dunstan]] had written an extensive guide to bell-ringing to mark the canonical hours.<ref name="bellsofengland">{{cite web |title=Church Bells of England |url=https://archive.org/stream/churchbellsofeng00walt#page/12/mode/2up |page=13 |date=1928 |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Walters, Henry Beauchamp}}</ref> Henry Beauchamp Walters' "Bells of England" features an entire chapter devoted to the regional variation in what bells were rung, how often, and what events they signaled throughout medieval England.
It is from these practices that clock chimes seem to have eventually emerged.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Loudspeaker on the Tower|url=http://www.davidtinapple.com/illich/2000_loudsppu.pdf |date=2001 |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Ilich, Ivan}}</ref> Clock towers that chimed on the hour appeared in Italy by the 13th century,<ref name="bellsofengland-2">{{cite web |title=Church Bells of England |url=https://archive.org/stream/churchbellsofeng00walt#page/12/mode/2up |page=173 |date=1928 |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Walters, Henry Beauchamp}}</ref> and they were common enough by the 15th that in 1463 the Englishman John Baret willed funds to the sexton of St. Mary's Church so that he would "keep the clock, take heed to the chimes, [and] wind up the pegs and the plummets as often as need is". <ref name="bellsofengland-3">{{cite web |title=Church Bells of England |url=https://archive.org/stream/churchbellsofeng00walt#page/12/mode/2up |page=111 |date=1928 |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=December 26, 2016 |author=Walters, Henry Beauchamp}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Westminster quarters]] * [[Whittington chimes]]
